annotation.summary: An introduction to the Starfinder roleplaying game, a science fantasy setting where players create characters to explore a galaxy filled with magic, technology, and alien civilizations. The game emphasizes collaborative storytelling and player choice in shaping adventures across diverse worlds following a mysterious historical event known as the Gap.
annotation.key_rules: Players create characters and collaboratively tell stories using structured game mechanics to resolve actions and outcomes. The setting blends science fiction and fantasy elements, with exploration, combat, and social interaction guided by rules that support narrative freedom.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified in this section; general gameplay involves players taking turns describing actions and resolving them through dice rolls and rule-based adjudication.
annotation.prerequisites: Basic understanding of tabletop roleplaying concepts and a group of players including a Game Master to facilitate play.

annotation.summary: A roleplaying game is a collaborative storytelling experience where the Game Master presents challenges and settings, and players control characters who respond to those situations through narrative and game mechanics.
annotation.key_rules: The GM describes the world and obstacles; players describe their characters’ actions to overcome those obstacles. Outcomes are determined by rules and chance.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified in this section; focuses on narrative interaction rather than mechanical turn structure.

annotation.summary: A tabletop role-playing game where one player acts as the Game Master (GM) to guide the story and challenges, while other players portray characters who respond to situations using their abilities and dice rolls to determine success or failure.

Players describe their characters' actions based on personality and abilities.
Dice rolls are used to introduce chance and determine outcomes of actions.
annotation.action_economy: Players take turns describing actions within scenes; outcomes are resolved through dice rolls and GM adjudication.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a group of 4–7 players, including one GM, and character statistics or sheets.

annotation.summary: Describes how Starfinder sessions are structured, ranging from short one-shots to long-running campaigns. Emphasizes flexibility in storytelling and the balance between action and narrative depending on player and GM preferences.

annotation.action_economy: Not explicitly defined in this section; focuses on session flow rather than turn structure or mechanical timing.

annotation.summary: The First Rule emphasizes that Starfinder is a collaborative storytelling game where player enjoyment takes precedence. Groups are encouraged to modify or ignore rules that hinder fun, shaping the game to fit their preferred tone and themes.

Rules can be changed or ignored if they interfere with fun.
All players should agree on any modifications.
The game supports a wide range of story types and settings.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section focuses on guiding principles rather than mechanical actions.

annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section focuses on player roles and character creation rather than in-game actions.

annotation.summary: This section explains the dice used in Starfinder, detailing the types of polyhedral dice, how they are notated, and how to interpret rolls involving multiple dice or percentile rolls.

Dice notation uses 'd' followed by the number of sides (e.g., d6).
A number before the 'd' indicates how many dice to roll (e.g., 4d6 means roll four six-sided dice).
Percentile rolls (d%) are made by rolling two d10s, one for tens and one for ones, to generate a result from 1 to 100.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section only covers dice mechanics.

annotation.summary: The game operates in three primary modes—exploration, encounter, and downtime—each defining the pacing and focus of play. Players transition between these modes as the story unfolds, with each mode emphasizing different activities and challenges.
key_rules: Exploration mode focuses on discovery, problem-solving, and interaction.
Encounter mode handles combat and other high-stakes conflicts.
Downtime mode covers rest, training, and recovery between adventures.
Gameplay naturally shifts between these modes as the narrative progresses.
annotation.action_economy: Varies by mode: encounters use structured turns and actions, while exploration and downtime use narrative pacing and broader time scales.

annotation.summary: Characters make checks to resolve uncertain or risky actions by rolling a d20 and adding a relevant attribute modifier. High rolls indicate better outcomes.
key_rules: Checks are used when the outcome of an action is uncertain or dangerous.
A check involves rolling one d20 and adding a modifier based on the relevant attribute.
Higher results on the roll indicate greater success.
annotation.action_economy: Checks occur when a character attempts an uncertain or risky action; they are not tied to a specific turn or action type unless specified by another rule.
annotation.prerequisites: The character must be attempting an action with an uncertain outcome or potential risk.

annotation.summary: This section explains how to resolve checks by comparing a rolled result to a target number called the Difficulty Class (DC), determining success, failure, or critical outcomes.
key_rules: A check succeeds if the total result is equal to or greater than the DC.
A check fails if the total result is lower than the DC.
Beating the DC by 10 or more results in a critical success, granting an especially positive outcome.
Failing by 10 or more results in a critical failure, often causing additional negative effects.
Rolling a natural 20 typically counts as a critical success before modifiers are applied.
Rolling a natural 1 typically counts as a critical failure before modifiers are applied.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this rule governs resolution of checks rather than turn-based actions.
annotation.prerequisites: A roll must be made against a defined Difficulty Class (DC).

annotation.summary: This section explains how critical successes and failures apply to skill checks. Not every check has special outcomes for critical results; if none are defined, treat them as normal successes or failures. An example demonstrates how a Piloting check can result in different narrative outcomes depending on the roll relative to the DC.
key_rules: If a check does not specify effects for critical success or failure, treat those results as normal success or failure.
A critical success occurs when the result exceeds the DC by 10 or more.
A critical failure occurs when the result is 10 or more below the DC.
The GM determines the DC and narrates outcomes based on the degree of success.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified; applies to general skill checks rather than specific actions.
annotation.prerequisites: A character must have an applicable skill and a situation requiring a check against a DC.

annotation.summary: This section explains how checks are resolved in the game, emphasizing that dice rolls combined with modifiers determine success or failure. Modifiers come from attributes, proficiency bonuses, and situational factors.

A check result is the sum of a die roll and relevant modifiers.
Modifiers include attribute modifiers, proficiency bonuses, and situational bonuses or penalties.
annotation.action_economy: Not directly addressed; checks can occur during any mode of play as needed.

Untrained grants a +0 proficiency bonus.
Trained, expert, master, and legendary grant bonuses equal to the character’s level plus 2, 4, 6, and 8 respectively.
Proficiency applies to most statistics in the game.
annotation.action_economy: None; proficiency modifies rolls rather than consuming actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; ranks are determined by character progression or class features.

annotation.summary: Exploration covers the free-form portions of play where characters move through environments, interact with others, and face challenges outside of structured encounters.
annotation.key_rules: Players describe their actions as their characters explore, investigate, travel, and interact with the world. The game master narrates outcomes and introduces challenges or discoveries based on those actions.
annotation.action_economy: No strict turn order or action economy; players act as the narrative flow dictates.

annotation.action_economy: No specific action economy applies; actions are narrative and preparatory rather than turn-based.
annotation.prerequisites: Active exploration phase with GM-player interaction.

annotation.summary: Encounters represent structured challenges in Starfinder where simple skill checks are insufficient. They typically involve combat but can also cover time-sensitive or high-stakes situations such as chases, hazards, or tense negotiations.
annotation.key_rules: Encounters occur when a challenge requires turn-based resolution or detailed timing. They define how characters and opponents act, react, and resolve outcomes beyond standard checks.
annotation.action_economy: Encounters generally use a turn-based system where participants act in sequence, managing actions within defined time units such as rounds.
annotation.prerequisites: Triggered when a situation cannot be resolved by a single skill check or when timing and order of actions are crucial.

annotation.summary: Encounters are structured sequences where participants act in initiative order over rounds of about six seconds each. Each participant takes a turn consisting of up to three actions, which can be spent on simple tasks or more complex activities.
key_rules: Encounters are divided into rounds, each lasting approximately six seconds.
Initiative determines the order of turns.
Each participant takes one turn per round.
A turn allows up to three actions.
Simple tasks typically cost one action.
Activities may require multiple actions, such as casting spells.

annotation.summary: The chunk explains that free actions do not count toward a character’s three actions per turn and that each character can use one reaction per round in response to specific triggers if they have an ability that allows it.
key_rules: Free actions do not consume any of the three actions available on a turn.
Each character can use one reaction per round.
Reactions occur outside a character’s turn and require an enabling ability or feature.

action_economy.reactions: One per round, triggered by specific events.

annotation.summary: The Strike action is used to attack another creature by making an attack roll against the target’s Armor Class (AC). Success deals damage, while a critical success deals double damage.
key_rules: Make an attack roll against the target's AC.
Use proficiency, attribute modifiers, and situational bonuses or penalties on the roll.
The target's AC is based on their armor proficiency and Dexterity modifier.
A hit deals normal damage; a critical success deals double damage.
annotation.action_economy: Requires one Strike action.
annotation.prerequisites: Must be capable of making an attack with a weapon, spell, or natural body part.

annotation.summary: This section explains how multiple attack penalties apply when making several Strikes in a turn, and outlines the mechanics of saving throws used to resist harmful effects targeting a character’s body or mind.
key_rules: Each additional Strike after the first in a turn incurs a multiple attack penalty: –5 on the second attack and –10 on the third.
The multiple attack penalty resets at the end of the turn.
Saving throws are checks made against the DC of a spell or effect targeting the character.
There are three types of saving throws: Fortitude (resisting physical harm or disease), Reflex (dodging area effects), and Will (resisting mental or emotional influence).
Success on a saving throw reduces the effect; a critical success often negates it entirely.
annotation.action_economy: Multiple Strike actions can be taken in a turn, each consuming an action; penalties apply to accuracy for subsequent attacks.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be able to perform Strike actions or be subject to effects requiring saving throws.

annotation.summary: This section explains how damage and conditions affect creatures in combat, describing how hit points represent health and how reaching 0 HP leads to unconsciousness or death. It also notes that conditions can temporarily or permanently hinder a creature’s abilities.

annotation.action_economy: Three actions per turn per creature.
annotation.prerequisites: Occurs during encounter turns; applies to all creatures.

annotation.summary: An ancestry defines a character’s species or heritage, determining their base physical and cultural traits such as Hit Points, languages, senses, and movement speed. It also provides access to ancestry-specific feats.
key_rules: Ancestry determines starting Hit Points.
Ancestry sets available languages and senses.
Ancestry defines base Speed.
Ancestry grants access to ancestry feats.
annotation.action_economy: None directly; ancestry affects character creation, not turn actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Chosen during character creation.

annotation.summary: Armor Class (AC) measures how difficult it is to successfully hit and damage a creature during combat.
key_rules: Every creature has an Armor Class value.
Armor Class functions as the target number (Difficulty Class) for attack rolls.
Higher Armor Class indicates greater protection or evasiveness.
annotation.action_economy: Not directly applicable; AC is a defensive statistic used when resolving attacks.
annotation.prerequisites: None; all creatures inherently possess an Armor Class.

annotation.summary: Describes how a creature performs an attack, typically by making a Strike or using another attack action to harm a target.
key_rules: An attack is an attempt to harm another creature.
Most attacks are Strikes made with a weapon.
A creature can also Strike unarmed, grapple, shove, or attack with a spell.
annotation.action_economy: Usually requires one action to perform a Strike or other attack action.
annotation.prerequisites: The creature must have a valid target and the means to make an attack (weapon, unarmed strike, spell, etc.).

annotation.summary: Describes the six core attribute modifiers that define a creature’s physical and mental capabilities.
key_rules: Each creature has six attribute modifiers: Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma.
These modifiers represent a creature’s innate potential and general training.
Further details about each attribute are provided later in the chapter.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section defines statistics, not actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all creatures.

annotation.summary: Backgrounds describe a character’s life experiences prior to adventuring, providing mechanical benefits and narrative context.
annotation.key_rules: Each background grants a feat and training in one or more skills.
annotation.action_economy: None; backgrounds are chosen during character creation and do not affect turn-based actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Selected during character creation; no other prerequisites.

annotation.summary: This section explains how bonuses and penalties affect checks and statistics, emphasizing that only the highest bonus and the worst penalty of each type apply.
key_rules: Bonuses and penalties modify checks and certain statistics.
Bonuses and penalties are categorized by type.
Only the highest bonus of a given type applies.
Only the worst penalty of a given type applies.
annotation.action_economy: None; this rule governs modifiers, not actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies universally to all checks and statistics.

annotation.summary: A check is used when a character attempts an uncertain action, resolved by rolling a d20 and adding the relevant proficiency bonus.
key_rules: Roll one 20-sided die (d20).
Add the appropriate proficiency bonus for the named skill or attribute.
Used when the outcome of an action is uncertain.
annotation.action_economy: Typically part of an action or reaction depending on context; the check itself does not consume a separate action.
annotation.prerequisites: The character must be attempting an uncertain action that calls for a check and possess any relevant proficiency.

annotation.summary: A class defines a character’s adventuring profession, shaping their abilities, proficiencies, hit points, and access to class-specific feats.
key_rules: A class determines a character’s proficiencies.
Each level in a class grants additional hit points.
Classes provide access to unique class feats.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section describes character creation elements rather than actions in play.
annotation.prerequisites: Character creation; a player selects one class when creating a character.

annotation.summary: A condition is a persistent effect that modifies a character’s abilities, actions, or statistics during play.
annotation.key_rules: Conditions impose specific mechanical changes on a character, such as altering movement, attack rolls, defenses, or other statistics. The details for each condition are defined in the Conditions Appendix.
annotation.action_economy: Conditions may restrict or modify available actions but do not inherently consume actions themselves.
annotation.prerequisites: None; conditions can be applied by effects, abilities, or environmental factors.

annotation.summary: Describes the game's standard currency and starting funds for new characters.
key_rules: The primary currency used in the game is credits.
Each character begins play with 150 credits.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section deals with resources rather than actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; applies to all starting characters.

annotation.summary: A feat is a special ability chosen for a character based on their ancestry, background, class, or training, granting new actions or enhancing existing ones.
annotation.key_rules: Feats are selected according to character origin or training and can either provide new abilities or improve current ones.
annotation.action_economy: Some feats introduce new actions; others modify how existing actions function.
annotation.prerequisites: Varies by feat—may depend on ancestry, background, class, or skill training.

annotation.summary: The Game Master (GM) oversees the game, interprets rules, and narrates the story and world for the players in Starfinder.
annotation.key_rules: The GM follows and applies the rules as outlined in the Starfinder GM Core book.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; the GM does not operate under player action economy.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires familiarity with the Starfinder GM Core rules and responsibility for managing gameplay and narrative.

annotation.summary: The setting describes the Pact Worlds, a coalition of planets that once included the lost world of Golarion, serving as the central hub for adventures across the wider galaxy in Starfinder.
annotation.key_rules: Provides context for the game's primary setting and references additional sources for expanded galactic details.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; this section focuses on setting lore rather than gameplay mechanics.
annotation.prerequisites: None; serves as background information for players and game masters.

annotation.summary: Hit Points (HP) measure a creature’s capacity to endure damage before falling unconscious or dying. Damage reduces HP directly, while healing restores it at the same rate.
key_rules: HP represent a creature’s durability or life force.
Damage reduces HP on a one-to-one basis.
Healing restores HP on a one-to-one basis.
A creature that reaches 0 HP falls unconscious and begins dying.
annotation.action_economy: Not directly applicable; HP changes occur as a result of actions that deal damage or provide healing.
annotation.prerequisites: Applies to all creatures with a defined HP value.

annotation.summary: Initiative determines the order in which creatures act at the start of an encounter, with higher rolls acting earlier.
annotation.key_rules: Each creature rolls for initiative at the beginning of combat; results are compared to establish turn order.
annotation.action_economy: Initiative establishes the sequence of turns but does not itself consume an action.
annotation.prerequisites: Occurs when an encounter or combat begins.

annotation.summary: Levels represent the overall power or difficulty rating of characters, creatures, items, and other game elements. They provide a standardized measure for balance and progression.
key_rules: Player characters have levels from 1 to 20, reflecting experience and growth.
Monsters, NPCs, hazards, diseases, and poisons have levels from -1 to 30, indicating their relative danger.
Items have levels typically from 0 to 20, showing their power and appropriateness as treasure.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; levels describe power scaling, not actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; level is a fundamental attribute assigned to entities.

annotation.summary: An NPC is a character managed by the Game Master that interacts with players and contributes to story progression.
key_rules: NPCs are controlled by the GM.
They serve narrative and gameplay functions, such as providing information, challenges, or assistance.
annotation.action_economy: NPCs act according to GM discretion, typically following the same or simplified action structure as player characters.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a GM to create and control the NPC.

annotation.summary: Perception represents a character's awareness and ability to detect hidden details or react to unexpected events.
annotation.key_rules: Used to notice hidden objects, detect unusual situations, and determine initiative order in combat.
annotation.action_economy: Typically a passive measure but may involve a check when actively searching or reacting.
annotation.prerequisites: None; all characters have a Perception score or modifier.

annotation.summary: Defines a Player Character (PC) as a character created and controlled by a player.
key_rules: A PC is distinct from non-player characters (NPCs) as it is directly controlled by a player.
The player determines the PC’s actions, decisions, and development during gameplay.
annotation.action_economy: Not specified in this chunk.
annotation.prerequisites: Requires a player to create and control the character.

annotation.summary: Proficiency represents a character’s skill level in various tasks, granting bonuses to rolls and statistics based on rank.
key_rules: Five proficiency ranks: untrained, trained, expert, master, legendary.
Proficiency applies to AC, attack rolls, Perception, saving throws, skills, and spell effectiveness.
Untrained grants +0 bonus.
Trained, expert, master, and legendary grant level +2, +4, +6, and +8 bonuses respectively.
annotation.action_economy: None; proficiency modifies rolls and statistics passively.
annotation.prerequisites: None; ranks are determined by character progression or class features.

annotation.summary: Rarity indicates how frequently a game element appears in the world, affecting availability and accessibility for characters. It helps GMs control distribution and narrative flavor.
key_rules: If no rarity is listed, the element is considered common.
Uncommon elements require special background, training, or cultural access, often detailed in an 'Access' entry.
Rare elements are difficult to obtain and typically granted by the GM.
Unique elements are one-of-a-kind within the game world.
The GM can modify rarity classifications to fit the story.
annotation.action_economy: None; rarity is a descriptive and narrative classification, not an action-based rule.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to uncommon or rarer options may require specific training, culture, or GM approval.

annotation.summary: Roleplaying involves players describing or speaking as their characters, embodying their perspectives and decisions within the game world.
key_rules: Players describe actions and dialogue from their character's perspective.
Speaking or acting as the character is referred to as being 'in character'.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; roleplaying is a narrative activity rather than a mechanical action.
annotation.prerequisites: None; all players can engage in roleplaying at any time.

annotation.summary: A round is a unit of time in an encounter where every participant takes their turn, representing about six seconds of in-game time.
key_rules: Each participant acts once per round.
A round equals roughly six seconds of game time.
annotation.action_economy: All participants act within the same six-second round, each taking their turn according to initiative order.
annotation.prerequisites: Occurs during an encounter or combat situation.

annotation.summary: A saving throw is an automatic roll made by a creature to resist or reduce the effects of a harmful condition or attack. The creature rolls a d20 against a DC set by the source of the effect.
key_rules: Saving throws are made automatically when a creature is subjected to a dangerous effect.
The creature being affected rolls the d20; the acting creature or effect sets the DC.
There are three types of saving throws: Fortitude, Reflex, and Will.
annotation.action_economy: No action or reaction is required to make a saving throw.
annotation.prerequisites: Triggered when a creature is subjected to a harmful or resistible effect.

annotation.summary: Skills measure a creature’s learned ability to perform specific tasks, reflecting training from background and class. Each skill outlines what can be done untrained and what requires training.
annotation.key_rules: Characters gain training in certain skills from their background and class. Skills define both trained and untrained uses, with detailed descriptions provided elsewhere.
annotation.action_economy: Using a skill may require an action, reaction, or no action depending on the specific task described for that skill.
annotation.prerequisites: Some skill uses require the character to be trained in that skill; others can be attempted untrained.

annotation.summary: Defines how far a character can move in one action, expressed in feet.
key_rules: Speed determines movement distance per action.
Movement is measured in feet.
annotation.action_economy: Requires one action to move up to the character's speed.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have a defined speed value.

annotation.summary: Spells are magical effects produced through incantations and gestures. They require specific actions to cast, have defined targets and effects, and can be resisted. Spellcasting ability details are found in class descriptions, while individual spells are listed separately.
key_rules: Casting a spell is typically a two-action activity.
Each spell defines its own targets, effects, and resistance mechanics.
Spells are categorized by rank from 1st to 10th, indicating their power level.
Classes that grant spellcasting describe the basics of that ability in their class entry.
annotation.action_economy: Usually requires two actions to cast a spell.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to a class or feature that grants spellcasting ability.

annotation.summary: A trait is a keyword that provides extra context or categorization for a rules element, indicating how it interacts with other parts of the game system.
key_rules: Traits identify additional information about a rules element.
They can denote ancestry, rarity, or other classifications.
Traits determine how other rules interact with the element.
annotation.action_economy: Not applicable; traits are descriptive and do not use actions.
annotation.prerequisites: None; traits are inherent to the rules element they describe.

annotation.summary: A turn represents the portion of a round in which a creature acts, following initiative order. Each creature typically has up to three actions to use during its turn.
key_rules: Each round is divided into turns, one per creature.
Turn order is determined by initiative.
A creature can usually perform up to three actions on its turn.

action_economy.turn_structure: Each creature acts once per round in initiative order.

prerequisites: Creature must be part of the initiative order.

annotation.summary: An example play session of Starfinder featuring a GM and four players guiding their characters—a vesk soldier, a pahtra solarian, a human witchwarper, and a shirren mystic—on a mission to investigate a disturbance near a Drift navigation beacon.
annotation.key_rules: Demonstrates basic gameplay flow including player roles, character archetypes, and the GM's narrative function in guiding the story.
annotation.action_economy: Not explicitly detailed; implied use of standard Starfinder turn structure with player and GM narrative exchanges.
annotation.prerequisites: Familiarity with Starfinder core rules and character creation.

annotation.summary: The party pilots their ship through a hazardous debris field in the Drift. Zemir attempts a Piloting check to navigate but rolls poorly, narrowly avoiding a crash while losing the intended course. Another character, Chk Chk, lightens the mood by sharing a poem in the group chat.
annotation.key_rules: A Piloting skill check is required to navigate through the debris field. Failure results in avoiding immediate collision but losing the plotted course.
annotation.action_economy: One Piloting check action; narrative roleplay action (poem reading) with no mechanical effect.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to a starship and the ability to make a Piloting skill check.

annotation.summary: The crew navigates a hazardous debris field in the Drift. Zemir attempts to pilot the ship through but rolls poorly, narrowly avoiding a crash and losing the intended course. Meanwhile, Chk Chk shares a poetic reflection on perseverance.
annotation.key_rules: Piloting skill check determines success or failure in navigating environmental hazards. A failed check can result in lost progress or potential danger but not necessarily immediate damage.
annotation.action_economy: One Piloting check action; narrative roleplay action by another player (no mechanical effect).
annotation.prerequisites: Access to a starship and ability to make a Piloting skill check.

annotation.summary: Group Chat is a mystic ability that allows Chk Chk and bonded allies to communicate telepathically, facilitating silent coordination and roleplay exchanges during spacefaring missions.
annotation.key_rules: The ability enables telepathic communication among bonded participants without the need for audible speech. It functions across normal communication barriers as long as the bond remains active.
annotation.action_economy: Typically a passive or free action once the bond is established; no additional action cost to communicate telepathically.
annotation.prerequisites: User must possess the mystic class feature or equivalent bond ability that grants telepathic communication.

annotation.summary: The crew pilots their ship through hazardous debris toward a mysterious beacon in hyperspace. Upon approach, they discover an armored ysoki clinging to the satellite. One crew member attempts telepathic contact but receives no response.
key_rules: Piloting check result determines success in navigating debris.
Telepathic communication can be attempted with nearby creatures.
Environmental hazards (debris field, hyperspace conditions) may require skill checks.

action_economy.Zemir: Used a Piloting check (standard action) to maneuver the ship safely.
action_economy.Chk Chk: Used an action to initiate telepathic communication with the ysoki.

prerequisites: Access to a ship capable of hyperspace travel.
Ability to use telepathy or similar communication power.

annotation.summary: During a tense space encounter, the crew installs a jetpack using the Quick Install feat, allowing Obozaya to attach it rapidly. Dae uses the jetpack to rescue a ysoki adrift in space, only to discover the ysoki is dead and something sinister may have boarded their ship. The team prepares for an imminent threat as eerie noises approach.

key_rules.Quick Install: A skill feat that allows a character to install an upgrade in 1 minute instead of the normal 10 minutes required for the activity.

annotation.action_economy: Quick Install reduces the time required for the Install Upgrade activity from 10 minutes to 1 minute, effectively improving downtime efficiency rather than affecting combat rounds.
annotation.prerequisites: Must have the Quick Install skill feat and access to an upgrade and compatible armor or equipment.

annotation.summary: The crew conducts a space rescue near a Drift beacon. Dae exits the airlock, activates a jetpack, and approaches a ysoki whose suit is damaged and whose face is frozen in terror. The team exchanges banter while coordinating the rescue.
key_rules: Space movement requires a jetpack or tether to prevent drifting.
Characters in vacuum must have functioning environmental protection or risk suffocation and exposure.
Observation checks may reveal environmental hazards or the condition of others in space.
annotation.action_economy: Dae uses a movement action to exit the airlock and a standard action to activate and maneuver with the jetpack toward the ysoki.
annotation.prerequisites: Access to a functional jetpack or similar propulsion system; environmental protection for vacuum exposure.

annotation.summary: The party returns to their ship only to find blood smears and signs of an intruder. Dae warns the crew and rushes toward the bridge, while the others prepare for a possible confrontation as scraping noises approach from outside.
key_rules: Perception or Investigation checks may reveal details about the blood smears or intruder.
Movement distances are measured in feet; Dae moves 60 feet toward the bridge.
Combat readiness actions include drawing weapons and taking defensive positions.

action_economy.Dae: Uses movement to reach the bridge area and a free action to communicate a warning.
action_economy.Obozaya: Uses an action to draw a weapon and move into a defensive position.
action_economy.Zemir: Uses an action to draw a weapon and prepare for combat.
action_economy.Chk Chk: Uses an action to draw a weapon and check on an ally.

prerequisites: Characters must be aboard a ship with defined interior spaces.
Players must have access to their weapons and basic movement capabilities.

annotation.summary: Thurston encounters two undead figures—a vesk and a human—wearing decayed spacesuits as an autodoor opens. Their milky eyes and rotting faces indicate they are reanimated corpses. Dae’s mystic bond with Chk Chk confirms Dae is alive and nearby.
key_rules: Mystic bond allows sensing the life status and proximity of bonded individuals.
Combat begins when undead appear; players must roll for initiative.
annotation.action_economy: Standard initiative-based combat sequence begins after the undead appear.
prerequisites: A mystic bond must be established between characters to sense life status.
Encounter triggers when the autodoor opens.

annotation.summary: During initiative determination, all participants roll Perception checks to set turn order. The GM records results from highest to lowest, including hidden rolls for unseen NPCs. Certain characters have abilities that trigger upon rolling initiative.
key_rules: Initiative is determined by rolling Perception.
The GM may roll secretly for hidden or unseen entities.
Abilities or effects may trigger immediately when initiative is rolled.
annotation.action_economy: This phase occurs before combat actions begin and does not consume any standard, move, or reaction actions.
annotation.prerequisites: Participants must be entering a structured encounter or combat scenario requiring initiative order.

annotation.summary: A player named Zemir activates a quantum field and uses a Focus Point to cast Warp Terrain, creating difficult terrain filled with debris from an alternate reality. The Solarian character attunes to the graviton mode and manifests a solar weapon before combat begins.
key_rules: Solarians can attune as a free action when rolling initiative.
Warp Terrain can be cast by spending 1 Focus Point.
Warp Terrain allows the caster to choose an effect, such as creating difficult terrain.

action_economy.free_action: Attune to graviton mode when rolling initiative.
action_economy.first_action: Spend 1 Focus Point to cast Warp Terrain.
action_economy.second_action: Make an attack with a laser pistol.

prerequisites: Character must be a Solarian or have access to attunement abilities.
Caster must have at least 1 Focus Point available.

annotation.summary: Zemir uses a Focus Point to cast Warp Terrain, creating difficult terrain filled with debris from an alternate reality. He then uses his next action to attack a vesk enemy with a tactical laser pistol, hitting and dealing 7 fire damage.
key_rules: Casting Warp Terrain requires spending 1 Focus Point.
The caster chooses an effect for the terrain, such as creating difficult terrain.
Attack rolls are made by rolling a d20 and adding the relevant attack bonus.
Damage is rolled according to the weapon’s damage dice and type.
Weapon ammunition or charges must be tracked and expended when used.
annotation.action_economy: 1 action to cast Warp Terrain (Focus Spell), 1 action to make a ranged attack with the laser pistol.
annotation.prerequisites: Ability to cast Warp Terrain (Focus Spell) and proficiency with simple weapons.

annotation.summary: Zemir uses his third action to take cover behind a rock, gaining a defensive bonus. The enemy driftdead attacks twice with void energy—missing once due to the cover bonus and hitting once for 6 damage—then moves toward another character but is slowed by difficult terrain.
key_rules: Taking Cover grants a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against attacks.
Attack rolls compare the attacker’s roll result to the target’s AC to determine hits or misses.
Difficult terrain doubles the movement cost for each square entered.
annotation.action_economy: Zemir spends his third action to Take Cover. The driftdead uses two actions to make ranged attacks and one action to move.
annotation.prerequisites: A character must be adjacent to or behind an object or feature that can provide cover to Take Cover.

annotation.summary: Chk Chk casts a psychic spell called 'vibe check' that forces an enemy driftdead to attack its ally after failing a Will save. Afterwards, Chk Chk transfers vitality to heal Zemir. The driftdead then retaliates by attacking Chk Chk.
key_rules: Casting a spell requires two actions.
The target makes a Will saving throw against the caster's spell DC.
On a failed save, the target must use its next action to attack the nearest creature.
Transfer Vitality heals an ally for a specified amount of Hit Points.

Chk Chk.actions_description: Casts 'vibe check' (2 actions), then uses Transfer Vitality to heal Zemir.

Driftdead.actions_description: Forced to attack nearest creature due to failed save.

prerequisites: Ability to cast psychic or mind-affecting spells.
Target must be capable of making a Will saving throw.

annotation.summary: Dae uses the Solarian feat Stellar Rush to dash through the hall into the bridge, pulling nearby enemies toward them with crackling black lightning after completing two Strides.
key_rules: Stellar Rush allows two Strides with a +10 circumstance bonus to movement speed.
After both Strides, enemies within 15 feet must attempt a Fortitude save against the user's Class DC.
On a failed save, enemies are pulled adjacent to the user.
The action has the cycle trait, shifting the user's attunement to photon upon completion.
annotation.action_economy: Single action that includes two Strides and a forced movement effect on nearby enemies.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be a Solarian with access to the Stellar Rush feat.

annotation.summary: Dae performs a dramatic, flame-infused attack against a vesk, scoring a critical hit and dealing significant damage.
key_rules: Attack roll compared to target's AC determines hit or miss.
A roll exceeding AC by 10 or more results in a critical hit.
Critical hits double the damage roll.
annotation.action_economy: One Strike action used to attack the target.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must be able to make a melee Strike and have a weapon or ability that can deal damage.

annotation.summary: Obozaya uses an Auto-Fire attack that targets all creatures in a 20-foot cone, but her bombard fighting style training allows her to exclude allies from the effect. Enemies make Reflex saves to determine damage taken, resulting in one enemy being knocked out and another heavily damaged.
key_rules: Auto-Fire attacks affect all creatures in a 20-foot cone.
Instead of the attacker rolling to hit, affected creatures make Reflex saving throws.
Damage is determined by the success or failure of the Reflex save.
Bombard fighting style training allows the attacker to exclude allies from area attacks.
annotation.action_economy: Standard action to perform an Auto-Fire attack.
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have access to Auto-Fire weaponry and bombard fighting style training to exclude allies.

annotation.summary: Obozaya uses Menacing Laughter as her third action, attempting to intimidate a driftdead. Despite rolling a natural 1 and failing to shake the foe, her previous attack leaves the driftdead suppressed with penalties to attacks and movement. Meanwhile, another driftdead phases through the floor to attack Dae.
key_rules: Menacing Laughter requires an Intimidation check against a target.
A natural 1 on the roll results in failure to inflict the shaken condition.
Suppressed condition applies a –1 circumstance penalty to attack rolls and –10-foot status penalty to Speed until the start of the attacker’s next turn.
annotation.action_economy: Menacing Laughter consumes one action (third action of the turn).
annotation.prerequisites: Character must have access to the Menacing Laughter ability and be able to make an Intimidation check.

annotation.summary: This chunk marks the transition between combat rounds in a tabletop RPG, noting that the second round begins immediately with the same initiative order and any new combatants added. It also lists major sections of the rulebook, covering character creation, progression, exploration, and reference materials.
key_rules: Combat proceeds in rounds with a consistent initiative order.
New foes can join combat at the start of a new round.
The listed sections outline the structure of the core rulebook.
annotation.action_economy: Each round follows the same initiative sequence; no new action types are introduced in this excerpt.
annotation.prerequisites: Players must have established characters and an initiative order before starting combat rounds.
